hdr100806-environmentalSustainability.def: Land spanning more than 0.5 hectare with trees taller than 5 metres and a canopy cover of more than 10 percent or trees able to reach these thresholds in situ. It excludes land predominantly under agricultural or urban land use, tree stands in agricultural production systems (for example, in fruit plantations and agroforestry systems) and trees in urban parks and gardens. Areas under reforestation that have not yet reached but are expected to reach a canopy cover of 10 percent and a tree height of 5 metres are included, as are temporarily unstocked areas resulting from human intervention or natural causes that are expected to regenerate.
hdr100806-environmentalSustainability.name: Forest area
hdr100806-environmentalSustainability.source: World Bank (2020a). World Development Indicators database. Washington, DC. http://data.worldbank.org. Accessed 22 July 2020.
hdr100806-environmentalSustainability.dataset: World Bank (2020a). World Development Indicators database. Washington, DC. http://data.worldbank.org. Accessed 22 July 2020.

hdr164206-environmentalSustainability.def: Percentage change in area under forest cover.
hdr164206-environmentalSustainability.name: Forest area
hdr164206-environmentalSustainability.source: HDRO calculations based on data on forest area from World Bank (2020a). World Development Indicators database. Washington, DC. http://data.worldbank.org. Accessed 22 July 2020.
hdr164206-environmentalSustainability.dataset: HDRO calculations based on data on forest area from World Bank (2020a). World Development Indicators database. Washington, DC. http://data.worldbank.org. Accessed 22 July 2020.

hdr174306-environmentalSustainability.def: Percentage of total energy consumption that comes from fossil fuels, which consist of coal, oil, petroleum and natural gas products.
hdr174306-environmentalSustainability.name: Fossil fuel energy consumption
hdr174306-environmentalSustainability.source: World Bank (2020a). World Development Indicators database. Washington, DC. http://data.worldbank.org. Accessed 22 July 2020.
hdr174306-environmentalSustainability.dataset: World Bank (2020a). World Development Indicators database. Washington, DC. http://data.worldbank.org. Accessed 22 July 2020.

hdr174506-environmentalSustainability.def: Number of deaths attributable to the joint effects of household and ambient air pollution, expressed per 100,000 population. The rates are age-standardized. The diseases taken into account are acute respiratory infections (estimated for all ages), cerebrovascular diseases (estimated for adults older than age 25), ischaemic heart diseases (estimated for adults older than age 25), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (estimated for adults older than age 25) and lung cancer (estimated for adults older than age 25).
hdr174506-environmentalSustainability.name: Mortality rate attributed to household and ambient air pollution
hdr174506-environmentalSustainability.source: WHO (World Health Organization) (2020). Global Health Observatory. www.who.int/gho/. Accessed 21 July 2020.
hdr174506-environmentalSustainability.dataset: WHO (World Health Organization) (2020). Global Health Observatory. www.who.int/gho/. Accessed 21 July 2020.

hdr174606-environmentalSustainability.def: Number of deaths due to diarrhoea, intestinal nematode infections and protein-energy malnutrition that are attributable to inadequate water, sanitation and hygiene services, expressed per 100,000 population.
hdr174606-environmentalSustainability.name: Mortality rate attributed to unsafe water
hdr174606-environmentalSustainability.source: WHO (World Health Organization) (2020). Global Health Observatory. www.who.int/gho/. Accessed 21 July 2020.
hdr174606-environmentalSustainability.dataset: WHO (World Health Organization) (2020). Global Health Observatory. www.who.int/gho/. Accessed 21 July 2020.

hdr181606-environmentalSustainability.def: Measure of the aggregate extinction risk across groups of species. It is based on genuine changes in the number of species in each category of extinction risk on the International Union for Conservation of Nature Red List of Threatened Species. It ranges from 0, all species categorized as extinct, to 1, all species categorized as least concern.
hdr181606-environmentalSustainability.name: Red List Index
hdr181606-environmentalSustainability.source: United Nations Statistics Division (2020a). Global SDG Indicators Database. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/. Accessed 21 July 2020.
hdr181606-environmentalSustainability.dataset: United Nations Statistics Division (2020a). Global SDG Indicators Database. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/. Accessed 21 July 2020.

hdr184306-environmentalSustainability.def: Number of people who died during or directly after a disaster as a direct result of the event or whose whereabouts are unknown since the event, expressed per 100,000 population. It includes people who are presumed dead, for whom there is no physical evidence such as a body and for whom an official or legal report has been filed with competent authorities.
hdr184306-environmentalSustainability.name: Number of deaths and missing persons attributed to disasters
hdr184306-environmentalSustainability.source: United Nations Statistics Division (2020a). Global SDG Indicators Database. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/. Accessed 21 July 2020.
hdr184306-environmentalSustainability.dataset: United Nations Statistics Division (2020a). Global SDG Indicators Database. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/. Accessed 21 July 2020.

hdr185006-environmentalSustainability.def: Rain-fed cropland, irrigated cropland, or range, pasture, forest and woodlands that have experienced the reduction or loss of biological or economic productivity and complexity resulting from a combination of pressures, including land use and management practices, expressed as a percentage of total land area.
hdr185006-environmentalSustainability.name: Degraded land
hdr185006-environmentalSustainability.source: United Nations Statistics Division (2020a). Global SDG Indicators Database. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/. Accessed 21 July 2020.
hdr185006-environmentalSustainability.dataset: United Nations Statistics Division (2020a). Global SDG Indicators Database. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/. Accessed 21 July 2020.

hdr186706-environmentalSustainability.def: Human-originated carbon dioxide emissions stemming from the burning of fossil fuels, gas flaring and cement manufacture, expressed in kilograms per unit of gross domestic product (GDP) in constant 2010 US dollars. Carbon dioxide emitted by forest biomass through depletion of forest areas is included.
hdr186706-environmentalSustainability.name: Carbon dioxide emissions
hdr186706-environmentalSustainability.source: United Nations Statistics Division (2020a). Global SDG Indicators Database. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/. Accessed 21 July 2020.
hdr186706-environmentalSustainability.dataset: United Nations Statistics Division (2020a). Global SDG Indicators Database. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/. Accessed 21 July 2020.

hdr195606-environmentalSustainability.def: Total carbon dioxide emissions produced as a consequence of human activities (use of coal, oil and gas for combustion and industrial processes, gas flaring and cement manufacture), divided by midyear population. Values are territorial emissions, meaning that emissions are attributed to the country in which they physically occur.
hdr195606-environmentalSustainability.name: Carbon dioxide emissions
hdr195606-environmentalSustainability.source: Global Carbon Project (2020). Global Carbon Atlas. http://www.globalcarbonatlas.org/en/CO2-emissions. Accessed 27 August 2020.
hdr195606-environmentalSustainability.dataset: Global Carbon Project (2020). Global Carbon Atlas. http://www.globalcarbonatlas.org/en/CO2-emissions. Accessed 27 August 2020.

hdr195906-environmentalSustainability.def: The sum of direct imports of materials and domestic extraction of materials minus direct exports of materials, measured in tonnes, divided by midyear population. A territorial (production-side) indicator, domestic material consumption measures the total amount of materials used in economic processes. It excludes materials that are mobilized during domestic extraction but do not enter the economic process. Domestic material consumption per capita, also referred to as metabolic profile, is an environmental pressure indicator that describes the average level of material use in an economy.
hdr195906-environmentalSustainability.name: Domestic material consumption per capita
hdr195906-environmentalSustainability.source: United Nations Statistics Division (2020a). Global SDG Indicators Database. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/. Accessed 21 July 2020.
hdr195906-environmentalSustainability.dataset: United Nations Statistics Division (2020a). Global SDG Indicators Database. https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/indicators/database/. Accessed 21 July 2020.

hdr196006-environmentalSustainability.def: Total agricultural use of fertilizer nutrientâ€”nitrogen (N) or phosphorus (expressed as P2O5), expressed per area of cropland. Cropland is the sum of arable land and land under permanent crops.
hdr196006-environmentalSustainability.name: Use of fertilizer nutrient nitrogen (N), per area of cropland
hdr196006-environmentalSustainability.source: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization) (2020b). FAOSTAT database. http://www.fao.org/faostat/en. Accessed 11 September 2020.
hdr196006-environmentalSustainability.dataset: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization) (2020b). FAOSTAT database. http://www.fao.org/faostat/en. Accessed 11 September 2020.

hdr196106-environmentalSustainability.def: Total agricultural use of fertilizer nutrientâ€”nitrogen (N) or phosphorus (expressed as P2O5), expressed per area of cropland. Cropland is the sum of arable land and land under permanent crops.
hdr196106-environmentalSustainability.name: Use of fertilizer nutrient phosphorus (expressed as P2O5), per area of cropland
hdr196106-environmentalSustainability.source: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization) (2020b). FAOSTAT database. http://www.fao.org/faostat/en. Accessed 11 September 2020.
hdr196106-environmentalSustainability.dataset: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization) (2020b). FAOSTAT database. http://www.fao.org/faostat/en. Accessed 11 September 2020.

hdr97106-environmentalSustainability.def: Total fresh water withdrawn, expressed as a percentage of total renewable water resources.
hdr97106-environmentalSustainability.name: Fresh water withdrawals
hdr97106-environmentalSustainability.source: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization) (2020c). AQUASTAT database. http://www.fao.org/nr/water/aquastat/data/. Accessed 21 July 2020.
hdr97106-environmentalSustainability.dataset: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization) (2020c). AQUASTAT database. http://www.fao.org/nr/water/aquastat/data/. Accessed 21 July 2020.

hdr97306-environmentalSustainability.def: Monetary valuation of energy, mineral and forest depletion, expressed as a percentage of gross national income (GNI).
hdr97306-environmentalSustainability.name: Natural resource depletion
hdr97306-environmentalSustainability.source: World Bank (2020a). World Development Indicators database. Washington, DC. http://data.worldbank.org. Accessed 22 July 2020.
hdr97306-environmentalSustainability.dataset: World Bank (2020a). World Development Indicators database. Washington, DC. http://data.worldbank.org. Accessed 22 July 2020.
